qas.question: how many tribes are credited with the creation of the modern day germans?
In modern day what is still influenced by the  five tribes?
What king united the tribes in the 9th century?
What part of Germany became mostly Slavonic-speaking due to migration?
The tribes that moved out of east Germany took to inhabit what fallen empires lands?
What five tribes are attributed with coalescing into a German ethnicity?

answers.text: Saxons, Franci, Thuringii, Alamanni and Bavarii

qas.question: What 6th tribe is sometimes included with the original 5 German tribes?
What century did King Charlemagne reign?
What modern ethnic group was formed by 6 migrating tribes?

plausible_answers.text: the large tribes which lived on the territory of modern Germany

qas.question: Who ruled the territory of modern Germany in the 900's?

plausible_answers.text: former areas of the Roman Empire

qas.question: Where did Slavonic tries migrate to from Eastern Germany?

context: The migration-period peoples who later coalesced into a <b9_0>"German"<b9_0/> ethnicity were the Germanic tribes of the <a5_0>Saxons, Franci, Thuringii, Alamanni and Bavarii<a5_0/>. These <a0_0>five tribes<a0_0/>, sometimes with inclusion of the <a6_0>Frisians<a6_0/>, are considered as the major groups to take part in the formation of the Germans. The varieties of the <a1_0>German language<a1_0/> are still divided up into these groups. Linguists distinguish low Saxon, Franconian, Bavarian, Thuringian and Alemannic varieties in modern German. By the <a8_0>9th<a8_0/> century, <b10_0>the large tribes which lived on the territory of modern Germany<b10_0/> had been united under the rule of the Frankish <a7_0><b11_0>king <a2_0>Charlemagne<a7_0/><a2_0/>,<b11_0/> known in German as Karl der Große. Much of what is now <a3_0>Eastern Germany<a3_0/> became Slavonic-speaking (Sorbs and Veleti), after these areas were vacated by Germanic tribes (Vandals, Lombards, Burgundians and Suebi amongst others) which had migrated into the <b12_0>former areas of the <a4_0>Roman Empire<b12_0/><a4_0/>.
